Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG, and 10Fe/AG samples. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The results of (a) XPS survey scan of the samples and high-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of (b) Fe2p and (c) C1s, and (d) FT-IR spectra of the composite catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 H2-TPR profiles of the (a) 1Fe/AG, (b) 5Fe/AG and (c) 10 Fe/AG samples. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 EPR spectra of AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG samples collected at room temperature. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 NH3-TPD curves of AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and (b) DFT pore size distributions of AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG samples. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Microtopography of 10Fe/AG catalyst: (a) FESEM images of the composite, TEM images of (b) geopolymer and (c) activated carbon parts, (d) high resolution TEM image of activated carbon part, (e) elemental mapping images and Fe3O4 particle size distributions of the activated carbon part, and (f) elemental mapping images of the geopolymer part. Table 2 Samples SBET (m2/g) Daverage (nm) Pore volume (cm3/g) <2 nm 2–50 nm >50 nm AG 492.66 3.01 0.086 0.376 0.001 1Fe/AG 454.96 3.08 0.069 0.343 0 5Fe/AG 428.06 3.11 0.067 0.336 0 10Fe/AG 405.09 3.07 0.068 0.313 0.003 Facile synthesis of cost-effective iron enhanced hetero-structure activated carbon/geopolymer composite catalyst for NH3-SCR: Insight into the role of iron species Hao Chen Methodology Writing - original draft Yao Jun Zhang Writing - review & editing Supervision * Pan Yang He Investigation Chan Juan Li Visualization Software Li Cai Liu Writing - review & editing College of Materials Science and Engineering, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi’an 710055, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology Xi’an 710055 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi’an 710055, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Materials Science and Engineering, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology, No.13 Yan Ta Road, Xi’an 710055, People’s Republic of China College of Materials Science and Engineering Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology No.13 Yan Ta Road Xi’an 710055 People’s Republic of China Graphical abstract A hetero-structure activated carbon/geopolymer composite catalyst enhanced with iron was fabricated via facile activated carbon embedded polymerization and controlled impregnation. Over the temperature window of 350-500 ℃, the as-synthesized catalyst exhibited NO conversion greater than 96.5%, N2 selectivity above 94% with stable durability, excellent SO2 and H2O resistance. The high NO conversion and N2 selectivity may be associated with synergistic effects of extra-framework iron species in the geopolymer rings and excessive iron species agglomerated to form FeOx clusters on the activated carbon surface with enhanced redox capability. These are attached to the composite catalyst’s unique hetero-structure, where the former provides active sites for lower temperature SCR while the latter provides reactivity at higher temperatures. The complex iron species in the catalyst are facile controllable through impregnation. This composite catalyst demonstrated a new approach for developing cost-effective NH3-SCR catalysts for practical implications. Keywords activated carbon geopolymer iron NO removal NH3-SCR 1 Introduction The increasing concentration of harmful nitrogen oxides (NOx) in the atmosphere originating from the fossil fuel combustions is one of the major global environmental concern, which are blamed as the main contributors of many environmental problems such as acid rain, photochemical smog, and the greenhouse effect [1,2]. Although various renewable energy sources have been developed to offset the conventional fossil fuel combustions, fossil fuels will remain as the dominant energy source for the foreseeable future [3,4]. Therefore, the most feasible method to reduce atmospheric NOx is its conversion into environmentally harmless products, and the most commonly utilized technology is selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR). The abatement efficiency and economic cost of NH3-SCR are primarily dependent on the quality of the catalyst [5]. Iron-based catalysts are widely used for NOx removal by NH3-SCR because of their pronounced thermal stability, excellent medium-high temperature reactivity and environmentally benign features. However, the temperature window of bulk Fe2O3 is limited, and the nonselective NH3 oxidation at high temperature also restricts its NOx conversion efficiency and N2 selectivity [6]. It is generally agreed that (a) the isolated iron monomers contribute to low-temperature selective reactivity, and they do not exhibit non-selective NH3 oxidation below 500 ℃, which provides the high N2 selectivity; while (b) the aggregated Fe species dominate the high-temperature reactivity [7–10]. Improvement of the reduced Fe species in the aggregated clusters also facilitates the NH3-SCR reactivity through enhancement of its redox capability [2,6]. Therefore, ongoing research focuses on the modification of Fe2O3 through the use of different supports or partial replacement of Fe with different elements to improve the dispersity and redox capability of the Fe species, and thus, promote the selective reactivity [6,11,12]. Zeolites are excellent catalysts supports owing to their eminent porosity and surface area, which facilitate the uptake and dispersion of active species [6–8,13]. It is widely accepted that the counter ions located at the extra framework of zeolites act as the selective catalysis centres [7,8] Numerous Fe/zeolite catalysts are reported for NOx removal by standard SCR or fast-SCR, and they exhibit satisfactory reactivity with wide temperature windows, high N2 selectivity, excellent SO2 tolerance and hydrothermal stability [14–16]. Geopolymers are a type of cementitious materials, which are usually prepared from alumina- and silica-containing natural minerals, industrial tailings, or their mixtures. These are blended with strong alkaline solutions, which serve as activators, and are converted to geopolymers under moderate curing conditions, involving the precursor dissolution, aluminosilicate oligomers transportation, as well as polycondensation [17]. The polycondensation process which separates the aluminosilicate species, combines them to form a stable three-dimensional network structure, providing the geopolymer matrix with excellent mechanical capabilities. Therefore, geopolymers are often used in construction and building materials, such as cements and concretes [18,19]. However, geopolymers are essentially analogues of zeolites, which are composed of [AlO4]5- and [SiO4]4- tetrahedral collected alternatively by sharing the bridging oxygens, while the negative charge of [AlO4]5- is balanced by the extra framework cations [20]. The chemical formula of geopolymers can be expressed as Mn{-(SiO2)z-AlO2}n•wH2O, where “M” represents an extra framework cation such as Na+ or K+, “n” is the polycondensation degree; and “z” represents the Si/Al ratio of the geopolymer [17]. It is noteworthy that the extra framework cation “M” is interchangeable, while the relative low Si/Al ratio of the geopolymers offer sufficient exchangeable sites. Therefore, geopolymers can be used for the purification of wastewater contaminated with heavy metal ions such as Ni2+, Cu2+ and Pb2+ [21,22]. More importantly, the ion-exchanged geopolymers also exhibit excellent catalytic capability since the exchanged cation at the extra-framework site is catalytic active as in zeolites [23,24]. When compared with zeolites, the preparation of geopolymers is hydrothermal free, consumes litter energy, low-cost and can utilize a broad variety of raw materials, and is more environmentally friendly [24–26]. Therefore, geopolymers are regarded as ideal candidates for environmental governance in both source control and end-of-pipe treatment aspects [27]. Nevertheless, it is agreed that the high valence state single bare cations tend to be located at six or eight-membered rings, while crystalline zeolites possess abundant uniform definite sized rings to accommodate these active bare cations [23]. However, although the monovalent cations (Na+ or K+) in the geopolymers are exchangeable, the distribution of rings in geopolymers exhibit wider size range owing to their medium-range disorder and amorphous structures [28]. Therefore, the proportion of single bare isolated cations in the geopolymer should be less than in zeolites after the ion-exchange treatment, and the excessive cations in the matrix are usually in the form of oxides [25,26]. However, regarding the NH3-SCR reaction, these excessive non-coordinated species usually result in the non-selective oxidation of NH3, and thus restrict the reactivity [29,30]. Activated carbon is also an excellent catalyst support owing to its high specific surface area and well-developed pore structures that benefit the catalyst dispersion and facilitate reactant adsorption for further catalytic reaction [31]. However, from the practical application perspective, the mechanical performance of activated carbon is insufficient for abrasion or rapid changes of temperature or pressure. Therefore, activated carbon is usually shaped or supported by binders such as resin or polyvinylidene chloride, however, these binders suppress the capabilities of the activated carbon [32,33]. In this study, we proposed the preparation of geopolymer-activated carbon composite by embedding of activated carbon into the geopolymer matrix via geopolymerization process. After curing, the composite obtained a certain mechanical strength, and then, iron cations were introduced into the composite by incipient wetness impregnation and calcination under protective atmosphere. During this step, the activated carbon in the composite emulatively undertake the excessive iron oxides, otherwise located on the geopolymer matrix. The iron oxides captured by activated carbon strongly bonded to the substrate, and are partially reduced to improve their redox capacity for NH3-SCR concurrently, thus avoiding the non-selective oxidation of NH3 at the same time. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials A mixture of mineral metakaolin and solid waste silica fume was utilized as the precursor material for the geopolymer, with the detailed chemical components and proportions recommended in our previous work [34]. Wood-based activated carbon with specific surface area of 1157 m2/g was supplied by Suzhou Charcoal Whirlwind Activated Carbon Co. Ltd. Analytically pure solid Fe(NO3)3•9H2O, NH4NO3, and KOH were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of iron enhanced activated carbon-geopolymer composite catalyst In a typical experiment, metakaolin, silica fume and activated carbon at a mass ratio of 12:8:6 were well blended to form a uniform powdery mixture. The alkali-activator was prepared by dissolving 24 g of solid KOH in 10 mL of deionized water at 60 ℃. After the solution cooled, the activator was poured into the prepared powdery mixture and stirred to obtain a slurry. This slurry was then cast in a 2 × 2 × 2 cm cubic mould, and subsequently sealed in a valve bag, and cured in an oven at 80 ℃ for 48 h. The compressive strength of the resultant activated carbon/geopolymer composite was 22.3 MPa. The composite block was then crushed into 0.8-1.0 mm particles. Subsequently, 5 g of the particles were added to a conical flask containing 100 mL 1 M NH4NO3 solution, and sufficiently stirred in a horizontal constant temperature oscillator at 80 °C and 150 rpm for 1 h for 4 times. The ammonium ion exchanged particles were then impregnated with aqueous Fe(NO3)3 solution to implement nominal iron loading contents of 1, 5 and 10%, respectively. After drying, the specimens were than calcined at 550 °C in a tube furnace under Ar protective atmosphere for 5 h to prepare the iron enhanced activated carbon-geopolymer composite catalysts, the catalysts were named 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG according to the nominal iron loading contents. An ammonium ion exchanged sample, which was also calcined under the same condition as that of Fe impregnated samples was named AG as referential specimen. 2.3 Characterization of the materials The powdery X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the specimens were obtained using a Rigaku D/Max 2200 X-ray diffractometer. The microtopography of the samples were observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, SU8010) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The specific surface area and pore size distributions of the samples were analyzed based on N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. The binding states of the surface elements of the specimens were observed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI surface analyzer. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of the materials were measured using a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer. Electron parameter resonance (EPR) curves were observed recorded on a Bruker EMXPlus-10/12 spectrometer at room temperature. The thermal stability and carbon content were conducted on a thermogravimetry (TG) equipment: approximately 20 mg of 10Fe/Ag sample was placed onto a columnar corundum crucible in the TG instrument, which was then heated at a rate of 10 ℃/min to 800 ℃ under gas flow or 3 vol.% O2 flow balanced by N2. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed with a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 equipment with 0.1 g sample that was pre-degassed at 300℃ under flowing argon for 1 h. After cooling, a H2 flow (40 mL/min, 10% H2+90% Ar) was introduced and the temperature was increased from 200 to 800 ℃ at 10℃/min. H2 consumption was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To increase the measurement accuracy and signal intensity, a cold trap was used to remove water and CO2 from the outlet gas before passing through the TCD. Ammonia-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 equipment with 0.1 g sample. The sample was pre-degassed at 300℃ under Ar flow for 1 h then cooled to room temperature, and the sample was exposed to 40 mL/min of 5% NH3 flow balanced by Ar for 1 h to ensure complete saturation with adsorbed NH3. Then, the temperature-programmed desorption was performed by heating at 10℃/min to 800 °C, and the ammonia desorption amount was observed using TCD. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements The selective catalytic reduction experiments were performed using a quartz fixed-bed micro-reactor operating under steady flow mode at atmospheric pressure. In a typical experiment, one-half gram of sample was placed in the quartz tube with a gas feed flow of 1000 ppm NO, 1000 ppm NH3, 3 vol.% O2, 300 ppm SO2 and/or 3 vol.% H2O (when used), and balanced by N2 with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 20000 h−1. The reaction temperature was varied from 150 to 500 °C, and recorded every 50 °C. The gas concentrations were monitored online using equipped Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer. NO conversion (XNO ) and N2 selectivity (SN2 ) were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) X N O = [ N O ] i n - [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % (2) S N 2 = 1 - 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n + [ N O ] i n - [ N H 3 ] o u t - [ N O x ] o u t × 100 % 2.5 In-situ DRIFT experiments In-situ DRIFT were performed on a Frontier FT-IR Spectrometer (PerkinElmer) equipped with a MCT detector and 10 cm Demountable Gas Cell. The 10Fe/AG composite catalyst was ground with KBr with a mass ratio of 1:100, then placed in the DRIFT reaction cell and pretreated at 400 ℃ under 20 mL/min Ar flow for 30 min to remove any adsorbed species. Subsequently, the temperature was decreased to 350 ℃ and the background spectrum was recorded, and automatically subtracted from the sample spectrum during the test. After that, the Ar flow was switched to a gas flow containing one or more reactants, such as 1000 ppm NH3, 1000 ppm NO and 3 vol.% O2, which was passed through the catalyst, and the spectra were recorded at various time intervals. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the as-synthesized composite catalysts XRD patterns of the AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG specimens are shown in Fig. 1 . The samples exhibit a broad hump peak centred at approximately a 2θ of 23°, which are assigned to the (002) surface plane of the activated carbon and amorphous structure of the geopolymer [34–36]. Two weak crystalline peaks at 2θ of 25.3 and 26.6° are attributed to the analcime and Gottardiite phases from metakaolin [36]. After iron impregnation and calcination, it can be seen that the 1Fe/AG exhibits nearly no differences with AG. This is possibly because that the Fe3+ ions are highly dispersed in the geopolymer and activated carbon matrix where they act as counter-ions and nano-FeOx clusters. Two crystalline peaks at 30.1 and 35.4° 2θ assigned to the (220) and (311) lattice planes of Fe3O4, are observed in 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG specimens, respectively. Since no Fe2+ ions were introduced into the system, the occurrence of Fe2+ can be attributed to the reduction of Fe3+ by the activated carbon, which also confirms the dispersion of Fe3+ on activated carbon [37]. More importantly, the lower oxidation states of iron oxide would be greatly beneficial for the SCR activities. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements were conducted to further confirm the state of Fe ions in the catalyst matrixes. The spectra were calibrated using C1s peak correction, and then analyzed using XPSPEAK software, where the Shirley background integration was utilized to determine the peak values and areas. Fig. 2 (a) displays the XPS survey scan of the samples, and shows that the catalysts are mainly composed of Si, Al, O and C, attributed to the geopolymer and activated carbon. More importantly, Fe2p spectra are observed on the 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG catalysts surface, but were absent on AG, suggesting that the iron was successfully loaded onto the composite. The detailed elemental mass compositions of the composites calculated from the XPS elements analysis results are summarized in Table 1 . The amount of activated carbon incorporated is approximately 23%, indicating limited carbon loss during the catalyst preparation processes. More importantly, the iron percent in 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG, and 10Fe/AG catalysts are 1.14, 4.96, and 10.35%, respectively, suggesting that the iron species are successfully impregnated on the composites with expected loading amounts. In general, for a bulk Fe2O3, the Fe2p3/2 peak is usually narrow and strong in intensity and accompanied by a satellite peak located at approximately 8 eV higher [38]. However, as seen in Fig. 2(b), the Fe2p3/2 peaks for all 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG catalysts are broad with a satellite peak located at approximately 6 eV higher, indicating the complex state of Fe ions in the catalysts. The peak separation between Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 is approximately 14.5 eV, implying the presence of both Fe2+ and Fe3+ in the catalysts [38,39]. The best fitting of the spectra suggests that the high-resolution spectra of Fe2p can be split into 6 peaks. The peaks at 711.12-712.46 eV and 724.76-725.52 eV are attributed to the Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 of Fe2+ and Fe3+ in FeOx clusters. The peaks at 713.34-714.63 eV and 724.76-732.70 eV are ascribed to the Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 of Fe3+ at isolated extra-framework sites of the geopolymer networks [40,41]. The peaks at 718.98-719.54 and 724.76-732.70 eV are the satellites of Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2, respectively. It is noteworthy that the Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 peaks of Fe2+ and Fe3+ in FeOx clusters and isolated Fe3+ shift to lower energies with increasing Fe loading amounts. The shift of the binding energy is attributed to the variation of the electron density around the atom, it is agreed that the greater electron density accounts for the lower electron binding energy [42–44]. Therefore, this may be because more electrons in activated carbon are transformed to the FeOx clusters; and when the isolated Fe3+ is saturated, the monomeric [FeOH]2+ are closer giving rise to internal condensation to form less bonded dimeric [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ [38]. As seen in Fig. 2(c), the C1s high resolution spectra can be split into three peaks at approximately 284, 286 and 288 eV, respectively, which represent C = C, C-O and COO groups [45], and the calculated area ratios of the SC=C/STotal for AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG are 0.87, 0.64, 0.67 and 0.63, respectively. Only Fe3+ ions are impregnated into the composite, the presence of FeOx is ascribed to the reduction of Fe3+ by reductive activated carbon. Therefore, this further confirms the interactions of the FeOx oligomers and activated carbon. Fig. 2(d) shows the FI-IR spectra of the samples. The band at 3400 cm-1 is attributed to O-H stretching vibrations, suggesting the existence of carboxylic, hydroxyl or chemisorbed water. The bands at 1404 and 1632 cm-1 are due to the O-C-O, C = C or CO stretching vibrations. The band at 1046 cm-1 is assigned to Si-O-Si stretching vibrations ascribed to the geopolymer network, while the shoulder at about 1100 cm-1 is related to C-O-C stretching vibration [46]. Peak at 460 cm-1 is attributed to the Al-O/Si-O bending vibration, contributed by the geopolymer matrix [47]. These results further confirm the XPS analysis. These results further confirm the XPS analysis. The valence state and redox capability of the catalyst are crucial indicators for NOx removal by NH3-SCR. Therefore, H2-TPR measurement was employed in this study to better understand the redox properties of the 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG catalysts. As seen in Fig. 3 , by using Peakfit software, the H2 consumption peaks of the catalysts are fitted with five temperature ranges, which are representative of the reduction of isolated Fe3+ to isolated Fe2+ in the geopolymer (305-366℃), the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 (406-473℃), the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO (520-589℃), the reduction of FeO to metal iron (615-638℃) and the reduction of isolated Fe2+ to metal iron (689-715℃) [48,49]. As observed, the reduction in temperature from isolated Fe3+ to isolated Fe2+ in 1Fe/AG is lower than that in 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG, suggesting the state of isolated Fe3+ in 1Fe/AG is different from that in 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG. According to XPS results, the Fe3+ in 1Fe/AG is mainly in the form of [Fe(OH)]2+, while in 10Fe/AG, the Fe3+ is mainly in the form of dimeric [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+. The internal condensation of [Fe(OH)]2+ to [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ ascribed to the increase in iron amount leading to the decrease in isolation and interactions of the ions within the geopolymer matrix, resulting in the increase of reduction temperature. The reduction temperature of FeOx to a lower oxidation state of 1Fe/AG is lower than that in 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG because the FeOx cluster in 1Fe/AG is smaller [50]. This is proven by XRD results where the Fe3O4 can be detected in 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG, but there are no Fe3O4 crystals that are observed in 1Fe/AG. Notably, although the reduction temperature of the isolated Fe3+ to isolated Fe2+ is lower than that of FeOx to lower oxidation state, the reduction of isolated Fe2+ to metal iron requires a higher temperature than that of FeO. Indeed, single bare Fe3+ usually cannot be coordinated as counter-ions since the rings in the geopolymer or zeolitic aluminosilicate materials cannot provide sufficient negative charges derived from [AlO4]5- tetrahedral, and they are often immobilized stably as [Fe(OH)2]+, [FeO]+, [FeOH]2+, [FeOFe]2+ or [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+. However, Fe2+ can be coordinated with the framework rings, but the framework will be collapsed when the Fe2+ is reduced to metallic iron, and thus it requires higher reduction temperatures [51,52]. Electron parameter resonance measurement is helpful to further understand the states of iron species in the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 4 , the EPR spectra exhibit two distinct signal peaks at g = 2.0 and g = 4.3, and the signals increase with increasing iron loading amount. It is accepted that the signal at g = 2.0 is ascribed to the isolated iron species or FeOx clusters, while the signal at g = 4.3 is attributed to the Fe species in tetrahedral positions with higher coordination numbers [53,54]. It is clearly seen that the signal intensity at g = 2.0 is much stronger than that of g = 4.3, suggesting the principal iron species in the catalysts are in the form of extra-framework isolated Fe3+ and nano-clusters, which consist well with the H2-TPR and XPS results. The surface acidity of the catalysts is an important factor that affects their NOx removal capability by NH3-SCR, and it is also plays a significant role in revealing the structure of the catalyst. Therefore, the temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 performances of the samples were measured as shown in Fig. 5 . The sharp peaks located at approximately 120 ℃ are attributed to the release of NH3 at weak acid sites. The broad peaks assigned at the higher temperature of approximately 324 ℃ are ascribed to the desorption of NH3 at strong Bronsted acid sites contributed by geopolymer (Si-O(H)-Al) and the activated carbon (-C-OH and -COOH groups) or Lewis acid sites ascribed to the extra-framework Al positions [55]. The appearance of new desorption peaks for 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG, and 10Fe/AG at high temperature of approximately 679 ℃ correspond to the strong Lewis acid sites formed by the highly dispersive Fe ions [55,56]. The AG exhibits strong NH3 desorption intensity than that of 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG, and 10Fe/AG samples at lower temperatures possibly due to its higher specific surface area and abundant Bronsted acid sites contributed by the geopolymer (Si-O(H)-Al) and the activated carbon’s (-C-OH and -COOH groups). Bronsted acid sites decrease with increasing Fe loading amounts owing to the substitution of H in hydroxyls in geopolymer and -C-OH and -COOH groups in the activated carbon by Fe3+ ions [57]. To further confirm the pore structures evolutions of the samples, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions (DFT method) of AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG specimens are given in Fig. 6 , while the relevant parameters are summarized in Table 2 . It can be seen from Fig. 6(a) that all the samples exhibit type IV isotherms with hysteresis loops at higher pressures and steep increases at near zero pressures, suggesting hierarchical pore structures [4], which are confirmed by the pore size distributions curve as shown in Fig. 6(b). The specimens possess both micropores at approximately 0.74 and 1.28 nm, and mesopores centred at approximately 3.85 nm. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas of AG, 1Fe/AG, 5Fe/AG and 10Fe/AG are as high as 492.66, 454.96, 428.06 and 405.09 m2/g with average pore diameters (Daverage) of 3.01, 3.08, 3.11 and 3.07 nm, respectively. Such a characteristic is of great significant for the reactant adsorption and subsequent catalytic reaction (Table 2). FESEM and TEM were employed to better understand the morphology of the hetero-structure composite and the composite supported iron catalysts. Fig. 7 (a) displays the FESEM image of 10Fe/AG catalyst, where it can be seen that the composite catalyst is composed of amorphous geopolymer gels and activated carbon particles, and there are clear interfaces between the geopolymer matrix and activated carbon. However, no more information about the iron species can be acquired. The activated carbon and geopolymer parts of the composite were then separately investigated using TEM. As seen in Fig.7(b), the geopolymer part of the composite catalyst exhibits a uniform, amorphous morphology, no iron oxide clusters can be observed, and the geopolymer is composed of aggregated nanoparticles. However, it can be seen in Fig. 7(c), that the activated carbon part of the composite carries many nano clusters with average diameter of 12.5 nm (Fig. 7(e)), while the high resolution TEM image of a cluster (Fig. 7(d)) exhibits clear lattice fringes. The space between the parallel fringes is 0.235 nm, matching the lattice plane distance between (311) surfaces of Fe3O4 [57]. Further evidence from the elemental mapping analysis as shown in Figs. 7(e) and (f) confirm that the iron species are homogeneously dispersed over the geopolymer matrix but agminated as nano-clusters on the activated carbon surface. 3.2 NH3-SCR reactivity and durability of the as-synthesized composite catalysts Fig. 8 (a) exhibits the NH3-SCR reactivity of the samples versus reaction temperature (100-500 ℃) under the condition of 1000 ppm NO, 1000 ppm NH3, 3% volume of O2 with the GHSV of 20000 h-1. AG possesses a high NO adsorption capacity below 250 ℃, which decreases with increasing temperature. AG also exhibits catalytic activity at higher temperatures owing to the presence of carbon oxygen groups in activated carbon and the Bronsted acid site (Si-O(H)-Al) contributed by the geopolymer [58]. However, the catalytic activity of these groups is limited, and the highest NO conversion is only 72.1% at the optimal temperature of 400 ℃. As for 1Fe/AG, it is interesting that the catalyst exhibits two NO conversion climaxes of 46.6% and 69.5% at the temperatures of 250 ℃ and 400 ℃, respectively, which results from different activity sites. As discussed in the above characterizations, Fe ions are highly dispersed in the geopolymer and activated carbon, the low Fe ion loading amount results in the formation of monomeric isolated [Fe(OH)]2+ specimens in the geopolymer rings and oligomeric FeOx clusters in activated carbon. The monomeric isolated [Fe(OH)]2+ affords the low temperature NH3-SCR activity, and the NH3-SCR activity at higher temperature is ascribed to the oligomeric FeOx. As seen that the 1Fe/AG exhibits nearly the same NO conversion trends as the AG during 300-500 ℃, but it possesses higher conversion at 450 and 500 ℃, thus confirming the contribution of FeOx, which exhibits the NO conversion activity at high temperature as literatures reported. As for the efficacy of monomeric isolated [Fe(OH)]2+, it can be further proved by higher Fe loading amounts reaction results. 5Fe/AG displays the same NO conversion tendency as that of 1Fe/AG during heating from 100 to 500 ℃, but the climax at 250 ℃ is weakened, while a new high NO conversion site at 350 ℃ is formed. This maybe because some of the monomeric isolated [Fe(OH)]2+ become closer with increasing Fe3+ loading amounts giving rise to internal condensation to form less bonded dimeric [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ which accounts for the reactivity at higher temperatures. Therefore, when further increasing the Fe loading amounts, the NO conversion climax for 10Fe/AG at 250 ℃ becomes negligible, while the conversion efficiency at 350 ℃ is more obvious. Moreover, with increasing Fe loading amounts, the formation of abundant dispersed Fe3O4 assists the NO conversion at higher temperatures of 400-500 ℃, and finally, the catalyst exhibits NO conversion greater than 96.5% over the temperature window of 350-500 ℃. Here, although the monomeric [Fe(OH)]2+ specie at the extra-framework of geopolymer exhibits a potential reactivity for low-temperature NH3-SCR, the limited pore content and insufficient effective rings that are assigned to the monomers location finally restrict its NO conversion efficiency. However, the as-synthesized hetero-structure composite is still an excellent catalyst that can be used for efficient abatement of NOx at medium-high temperatures. Geopolymers are essentially analogous to zeolites, which are composed of [AlO4]5- and [SiO4]4- tetrahedral collected alternatively by sharing the bridging oxygens, while the negative charge of [AlO4]5- is balanced by the extra framework cations. The biggest difference between the geopolymers and the zeolites is that geopolymers are amorphous or quasi-crystalline structures, while zeolites are crystalline ordered structures with uniform pore size distributions, thus the preparation of catalysts using zeolites as supports is controllable. Therefore, the biggest challenge using the geopolymers as support to prepare SCR catalyst with proper structures accommodating sufficient monomeric iron species is to endow the geopolymer with controllable pore structures. Structure-directing agents may be a satisfactory choice. By utilizing structure-directing agents to enable geopolymers with ordered rings like SSZ-13 or ZSM-5, the as-prepared geopolymers may exhibit excellent low-temperature NH3-SCR performance similar to that of zeolites. Fig. 8(b) displays the N2O yields and N2 selectivity of the catalysts during NH3-SCR reaction under the same condition as Fig. 8(a), it can be seen that all the catalysts produce limited N2O byproducts, which are less than 60 ppm, and the N2 selectivity are higher than 94% at the temperature ranges of 100-500 ℃ in spite of the decrease tendency with increasing temperatures. Fig. 8(c) shows the NO conversion over iron exchanged geopolymer catalysts without activated carbon. The iron exchanged geopolymer catalysts are prepared through the same process as that of activated carbon-geopolymer composite catalyst. 1Fe/GEO and 5Fe/GEO catalysts exhibit high NO conversion extremum at 250 ℃, confirming that the geopolymer portion is responsible to the low temperature activity. Notably, 10Fe/GEO exhibit higher NO conversion at higher temperatures, this may be because the excessive iron species are agglomerated to form FeOx clusters. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), the NO conversion decreases with increasing GHSV, and shows similar trends as a function of temperature. This is because the higher GHSV indicates higher velocity the flow gas passes through the catalyst, resulting a shorter residence time on the catalyst bed and an incomplete reaction. However, when the GHSV is less than or equal to 20000 h-1, NO conversions remain higher than 96.5% in the temperature ranges of 350-500 ℃.Fig. 9(b) shows the effects of [NH3]/[NO] ratio on NO conversion and N2 selectivity over 10Fe/AG at 350 ℃, 1000 ppm NO and 3% volume of O2 with the GHSV of 20000 h-1. As observed, the NO conversion increases with increasing [NH3]/[NO] ratios, and equilibrium is achieved when the [NH3]/[NO] ratio increases to 1. The NO conversion cannot be further enhanced with additional NH3, which may be because the NH3-SCR of NO is controlled by the following standard SCR reaction: (3) 4 N O + 4 N H 3 + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O Fig. 9(c) exhibits the effect of O2 concentration on NO conversion and N2 selectivity over 10Fe/AG at 350℃, 1000 ppm NO, and 1000 ppm NH3 with the GHSV of 20000 h-1. As seen that the NO conversion increases with increasing O2 concentration below 3% volume, and the conversion also cannot be further improved with additional O2. Moreover, the N2 selectivity is maintained higher than 96%, which may be evident of the fact that limited NH3 is oxidized by O2 according to equation (4), thus guaranteeing the high selective NO conversion and N2 selectivity. (4) 2 N H 3 + 2 O 2 → N 2 O + 3 H 2 O Fig. 9(d) exhibits the effect of NO concentration on NO conversion and N2 selectivity over 10Fe/AG at 350 ℃, [NH3]/[NO] = 1 and 3% volume of O2 with the GHSV of 20000 h-1. The 10Fe/AG catalyst maintains high NO conversion and N2 selectivity in the NO concentration ranges of 200-1800 ppm, suggesting the as-synthesized catalyst can treat flue gases with wide concentration ranges. Durability and stability are important indicators of the catalyst, as seen from Fig. 10 (a) that after the long-term reuse of the 10Fe/AG catalyst at 350 ℃, 1000 ppm NO, 1000 ppm NH3, 3% volume of O2 with the GHSV of 20000 h-1, it maintains high NO conversion and N2 selectivity, indicating its outstanding durability and stability. In practical industrial applications, the ubiquitous existence of H2O or/and SO2 could affect the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Therefore, the influence of H2O and SO2 on the NH3-SCR reactivity of the as-synthesized 10Fe/AG catalyst was conducted at 350 ℃ under the condition of 1000 ppm NH3 and NO, 3 vol.% O2, 300 ppm SO2 and/or 3 vol.% H2O with the GHSV of 20000 h-1, and the results are shown in Fig. 10(b). It is visible that after the introduction of 300 ppm SO2, the NO conversion was decreased to approximately 90.2%. However, the NO conversion was then slightly increased to 91.5% for the following 2 h and kept steady, this may be because the adsorbed SO2 acted as new acid sites and enhanced the NH3 adsorption and activation. However, after the introduction of 3 vol.% H2O for 1 h, the NO conversion was reduced to 86.7% maintained, without further enhancement of NO conversion efficiency. After the simultaneous introduction of 300 ppm SO2 and 3 vol.% H2O, the NO conversion was directly reduced to 87.7% for 1 h and kept steady. Notably, the NO conversions recovered to 97.6% when the H2O and/or SO2 supply was discontinued, suggesting excellent H2O and SO2 resistance and self-healing performance of the as-synthesized composite catalysts. Fig. 11 (a) shows the TG weight loss of 10Fe/AG catalyst under air and 3 vol.% O2 flow in the temperature ranges of 35-800 ℃. For both condition, there are two weight loss regions 35-150 ℃ and 150-400 ℃, which are ascribed to the release of physical and chemical adsorbed water, respectively [59]. However, while under air flow, and with further increase in temperature, the activated carbon in the composite was consumed with a weight loss of approximately 23.3%. This value compares well with the XPS analysis. In contrast, the weight of the catalyst remained steady under 3 vol.% O2 flow when the temperature was higher than 400 ℃, suggesting that the activated carbon would not be consumed during the SCR test. As shown in Fig. 11(b), the functional groups related to the activated carbon at 3440, 1640, and 1063 cm-1 exhibit limited changes after the SCR test. The pore structures, as visible in Fig. 11(c), also exhibit inconspicuous variations after the SCR test. More importantly, the high resolution Fe2p spectrum of the 10Fe/AG catalyst shows no obvious binding energy shift or variation in peak width, indicating its excellent redox stability. 3.3 NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over the as-synthesized composite catalysts In situ DRIFT experiment was conducted to better understand the SCR reaction mechanism over the as-synthesized composite catalyst. Fig. 12 (a) shows the NH3 adsorption spectra of the catalyst at different time intervals. Several bands at 1246, 1361, 1605 cm-1 are observed when exposed to 1000 ppm NH3 for about 5 min, and the bands maintain stable after 40 min, suggesting the saturation of NH3 adsorption. The bands at 1246 and 1605 cm-1 are ascribed to the asymmetry and symmetry deformation of modes of NH3 at Lewis acid sites [60], while the bands at 1361 cm-1 is ascribed to the N-O stretching vibration, which indicates the oxidization of adsorbed ammonia species [61]. In situ DRIFT results of feeding 1000 ppm NO + 3 vol.% O2 over the 10Fe/AG catalyst for various time intervals are shown in Fig. 12(b). Several bands at 1281, 1419, 1612 cm-1 are clearly observed for 10 min, and the adsorption was saturated for 40 min. The bands at 1281 cm-1 are attributed to the formation of monodentate nitrate [62]. The bands at 1419 cm-1 are the N-stretching mode of trans-N2O2 2− [63]. The bands at 1612 are corresponded to gaseous NO2 [61]. As shown in Fig. 12(c), after the exposure of NH3 saturated composite catalyst to 1000 ppm NO + 3 vol.% O2 for 20 min, the band at 1361 cm-1 was gradually disappeared, indicating the consumption of adsorbed oxidization ammonia species. A new band at 1405 cm-1 ascribed to the nitrite species was formed after 40 min [64], suggesting the co-adsorption of NO and O2 on the catalyst when their feeding was excessive. However, the bands at 1246 and 1605 cm-1 corresponded to the coordinated NH3 species at Lewis acid sites exhibited limited variations, demonstrating these ammonia species were unreactive under this temperature. Further, when exposure of NO and O2 saturated composite catalyst to 1000 ppm NH3 for 20 min, as shown in Fig.12 (d), the band at 1281 cm-1 ascribed to the monodentate nitrate species was gradually shifted to lower value of 1246 cm-1, indicating that the monodentate nitrate species at Lewis acid sites were consumed and replaced by ammonia. Meanwhile, the bands at 1420 cm-1 corresponded to the trans-N2O2 2− species were transformed into nitrite species (1405 cm-1). Hence, the adsorbed NH3 and NO species on the catalyst are partially reactive, while the adsorbed oxidization ammonia species and monodentate nitrate species are important intermediates that participate in the SCR reaction over the as-synthesized composite catalyst, implying that both the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanisms govern the reaction [62]. 4 Conclusion Nitrogen oxides originating from fossil fuel combustion are one of the major global environmental concerns, NH3-SCR is considered as a feasible strategy for NOx abatement, while the development of high performance and cost-effective catalyst is the core content of this technique. In this study, a batch of low-cost hetero-structure iron enhanced activated carbon/geopolymer composites with different iron loading amounts were originally prepared and assessed for NO elimination by NH3-SCR. Results reveal that the selective reactivity of the composites increases with increasing iron loading amount. The high SCR reactivity of the composite at medium-high temperature is attributed to the synergistic effect of the isolated iron in the geopolymer rings and FeOx nano clusters located on the activated carbon surface, the former provides active sites for medium temperature SCR, whereas the latter affords the reactivity at high temperatures. Although the monomeric [Fe(OH)]2+ specie at the extra-framework of the geopolymer exhibit a potential reactivity for low-temperature NH3-SCR, the limited pore content and insufficient effective rings that assigned for the monomers location finally restrict its NO conversion efficiency, Hence, the as-synthesized composite catalyst is of great significant for the practical industrial implications in the temperature range of 350-500 ℃, 3 vol.% O2 with wide GHSV of 10000–20000 h-1, initial NO concentration of 200-1800 ppm, and excellent SO2 and H2O resistance. More importantly, the as-synthesized activated carbon-geopolymer composite catalyst reported here is cost-effective, facile to prepare, and possesses high compressive strength to meet the practical application requirements that traditional powdery zeolites or metal oxide catalysts lack of. The further development of geopolymers with proper structures accommodating sufficient monomeric iron species for low-temperature NH3-SCR will be reported in our future works. coredata.dc:description: A hetero-structure activated carbon/geopolymer composite catalyst enhanced with iron was fabricated via facile activated carbon embedded polymerization and controlled impregnation. Over the temperature window of 350-500 ℃, the as-synthesized catalyst exhibited NO conversion greater than 96.5%, N2 selectivity above 94% with stable durability, excellent SO2 and H2O resistance. The high NO conversion and N2 selectivity may be associated with synergistic effects of extra-framework iron species in the geopolymer rings and excessive iron species agglomerated to form FeOx clusters on the activated carbon surface with enhanced redox capability. These are attached to the composite catalyst’s unique hetero-structure, where the former provides active sites for lower temperature SCR while the latter provides reactivity at higher temperatures. The complex iron species in the catalyst are facile controllable through impregnation. This composite catalyst demonstrated a new approach for developing cost-effective NH3-SCR catalysts for practical implications.
coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of cost-effective iron enhanced hetero-structure activated carbon/geopolymer composite catalyst for NH3-SCR: Insight into the role of iron species
